Award.AwardTitle: The Catalytic Mechanism of Oxalate Decarboxylase Studied by Advanced EPR Techniques
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this award from the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division, Dr. Alexander Angerhofer, from the University of Florida, will study the molecular mechanisms by which the bacterial enzyme oxalate decarboxylase (OxDC) and specific site-directed mutants catalyze the cleavage of the carbon-carbon bond in oxalic acid. This enzyme may have important applications in the control of oxalic acid which is one of the most common naturally occurring toxins and the main ingredient in kidney stones. Advanced electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) and electron nuclear double resonance (ENDOR) techniques will be used to study the electronic structure and local coordination environment of two Mn ions in the protein subunit where catalysis takes place. Spin trapping will be used to investigate free radicals that are released from the protein during enzymatic turnover. Binding of substrate and various inhibitors to the enzyme will be studied with high-field EPR. These experiments will yield important kinetic, thermodynamic, and structural information about binding of substrate and inhibitors to the enzyme, and will test the current working hypothesis in which Mn and an associated bound oxygen molecule act as redox shuttles in the breaking of the oxalate C-C bond. The possible existence of a long-range electron transfer chain in the protein and its role in the catalytic process will also be investigated. While OxDC is of interest in its own right and may lead to future treatments of various oxalate-related pathologies (hyperoxaluria, kidney stones, etc.), the enzyme will also serve as an example of how a protein can control reactive radical intermediates. Site-directed mutants have been generated that have decreased oxalate decarboxylase but increased oxalate oxidase activites. Work with these mutants will help to elucidate how the structure of the active site can guide the chemistry and switch between decarboxylase and oxidase activities.

This project is tightly integrated into Howard Hughes Medical Institute "Science for Life" initiative at the University of Florida, which serves its undergraduate student population by bringing them into research labs early on. Each year on average two of the most promising undergraduate science majors will be directly supported in this project in the summer of their sophomore or junior years. They will have additional volunteer opportunities and perform research for credit toward their degrees which allows them to write an honors thesis during their senior year. These students will receive intensive mentoring by Dr. Angerhofer and his collaborators and will be given the opportunity to perform cutting-edge research, which will not only enrich their education but also provide them a perspective for a future career in the natural sciences. They will also have the opportunity to present their research at local, regional, and national scientific conferences. Dr. Angerhofer will make every effort to recruit students from groups that are underrepresented in the STEM disciplines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Oxalic acid is produced by plants and is the major naturally occuring environmental toxin. Accumulation in mammals through diet may lead to kidney stones, hyperoxaluria, and may be lethal depending on the dose. Oxalic acid is degraded in the soil by soil bacteria using the enzyme oxalate decarboxylase (OxDC) to help regulate intracellular pH. The big question addressed in this award is how OxDC is able to catabolize oxalic acid using two different types of chemistry, decarboxylation and oxidation. Decarboxylation can be described as a unimolecular disproportionation reaction which is redox-neutral but it requires dioxygen as a co-catalyst. The initial step appears to be an oxidation step which is followed by a reduction step to form the product, formate. A secondary reaction is fully oxidative where the monoanion of oxalic acid is dissociated into two equivalents of carbon dioxide while at the same time oxygen is reduced to hydrogen peroxide, i.e., oxygen is used up. The key to our understanding of how OxDC functions is found in the analysis of the radical intermediates during turnover and in the redox chemistry of the metal co-factors of OxDC, two tightly bound Mn ions per protein subunit. Important progress was made on both accounts leading to revisions of long-standing hypotheses about the enzymatic mechanism.

1. Using electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spin trapping we were able to prove that the carbon dioxide radical anion as well as the superoxide anion are catalytic intermediates. The observation of superoxide during turn-over is new and is a key event in the initial step for both decarboxylation and oxidation reactions. Using the site-directed mutant T165V of OxDC we were able to show that the production of both radicals is modulated in different ways by the amino acid side chain strongly suggesting that the two radicals are generated at different locations in the protein. This has led to a new proposal of a long-range electron transfer bridging the two Mn locations.

2. Using parallel mode EPR in the X-band in conjunction with high field EPR at 400 GHz we were able to show the presence of Mn(III) not only during turnover but also prior to catalysis. We were able to show that the N-terminal Mn(II) has a slightly smaller Mn(II)/Mn(III) standard potential than the C-terminal one favoring it as the redox active catalytic site in agreement with mechanistic proposals in the literature. More importantly, the pH dependence of Mn(III) is very similar to the pH dependence of enzyme activity strongly suggesting a causal link. The simplest explanation is that Mn(III) is driving the reaction. We were also able to show that the observation of Mn(III) in low pH enzyme is only possible in the presence of small carboxylate molecules such as formate, acetate, and succinate. When citrate buffer is used, the parallel mode Mn(III) EPR signal does not appear. The simplest explanation for this interesting result is that the coordination of a small negatively charged carboxylate ligand stabilizes Mn(III) in the N-terminal binding site and allows for the induction of electron transfer to dioxygen which sets the stage for subsequent catalysis if that carboxylate ligand is oxalate.

3. We were able to obtain the first low-pH crystal structure of OxDC showing the active state of the enzyme. An acetate molecule is bound to the N-terminal Mn site. Interestingly, the flexible SENS161-4 loop is in an intermediate position between the previously known open and closed form and E162 is turned away from the active site making it doubtful that it can serve as a transient base to facilitate proton-coupled electron transfer as the first step.

 

The biggest broader impact of this award even beyond science and technology lies in the human capital that has been built and enhanced. A total of 21 undergraduate students have participated in the process of generating knowledge through the scientific process during this award. Five graduate students have been trained, three of whom have since graduated two with their PhD degrees and one with his MS.

Some of the undergraduate students involved have graduated with highest honors and have moved on to post-graduate education where they will benefit from the skills they have learned during their time in our lab. Others are still working with us and are getting hands-on experience of how scientific knowledge is created through hard work and often trial and error. One of the PhD graduates has found employment as a postdoctoral associate at Emory University and is planning an academic career. The MS student is currently enrolled in a PhD program at a university in Spain. Another PhD student just recently defended his thesis and is now ready to enter the workforce. Two more students are in their 4th and 2nd year of graduate school, respectively, and are making good progress toward their PhD.
